how can we apply our integrated business resilience framework to these slides, particularly to apply our clients needs here: "Include consideration of the relevance of integrating green elements, of having green as a competitive advantage (+ maybe a way of attracting investors) See ‚ÄòGreen Business Booklet‚Äô page 12 + 16 for tips on how to come up with a green business idea, and/or think greening into the different parts of the business plan" here is the section from the booklet they referred to attached. What do you think of the slides and how can we improve them and the facilitator notes? YOUR GREEN
BUSINESS IDEA
This chapter of the GBB complements the
Generate Your Business (GYB) manual in the
SIYB family of products. The GYB manual
will help you to determine whether you have
the right characteristics to become an en-
trepreneur, to generate business ideas using
different sources, and to assess and pick the
best idea.
This chapter of the GBB helps you to do the
above from a green perspective. While this
chapter is primarily intended for aspiring en-
trepreneurs in search of a business idea, it
may also prove useful for entrepreneurs who
already have a business but would like to di-
versify their product or service range.
2.1
Do I have the right
characteristics to become a
green entrepreneur?
Green entrepreneurs are involved in the pro-
duction of environmentally friendly products
and services or make use of processes that
are environmentally friendly.
Green entrepreneurs like any other entrepre-
neurs need to possess certain characteris-
tics to be successful. These characteristics
(passion; goal-orientation; decision-making;
risk-taking; ability to handle stress; ability
to access to social support; financial endow-
ment; business management skills) are dis-
cussed in detail in the GYB manual.
In addition to these general characteristics,
green entrepreneurs need to think about the
planet and its people along with profit, so
some further characteristics are required.
When completing the assessment in the
GYB manual, we recommend you also re-
flect on whether you have these additional
characteristics.
A GREEN ENTREPRENEUR NEEDS TO BE:
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
Analytical ‚Äì As the green sector is rela-
tively new, entrepreneurs venturing into it
need to be able to analyze the potential for
success and failure and plan accordingly.
Innovative ‚Äì Green entrepreneurs need
to be able to ‚Äúthink outside the box‚Äù and
come up with new solutions to address en-
vironmental problems.
Committed to ethical standards ‚Äì A green
entrepreneur needs to think about profit,
but also about people and the planet (the
3 ‚ÄúP‚Äùs) when making business decisions.
When developing green business ideas, consider your future market and
resources that can be availed. This Zambian architect decided to take an
eco-friendly approach while building affordable houses.
GREEN BUSINESS BOOKLET
| 11
2.2
Coming up with your
green business idea
Your green idea is the starting point for your
green business.
The GYB manual provides guidance on many
different ways of coming up with business ide-
as. These include learning from business peo-
ple, drawing from your own and other people‚Äôs
experiences, surveying your local business area,
scanning your environment and structured and
unstructured brainstorming.
A green business idea can relate to either a
green product or a green service, or it can re-
late to a ‚Äústandard‚Äù product or service, but
which is produced or delivered in a green way.
Some examples of green ideas are provided in
the box below.
SOME GREEN BUSINESS IDEAS:
‚Ä¢
Organic fertilizer
‚Ä¢
Organic beauty products
‚Ä¢
Biodegradable packaging
‚Ä¢
Organic restaurant
‚Ä¢
Souvenirs made from waste
‚Ä¢
Eco-tourism
‚Ä¢
Green building materials
‚Ä¢
Eco-friendly transport service
In order to come up with a green business
idea, you may use the brainstorming exercise
below to complement the exercises in the GYB
manual, thinking about what environmental
problems need to be solved in your community
and about what resources in your community
could be tapped into:
ENVIRONMENTAL PROBLEMS IN THE COMMUNITY
1a. What health
and environmental
problems exist in
your community?
1b. What is al-
ready being done
to address these
problems?
1c. What is not
yet being done at
all, or what is not
being done well?
NATURAL RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN THE COMMUNITY
2a. Does your
community have
any natural re-
sources or waste
products that
could be used for
business?
2b. Are there
already some
businesses in your
community that
make use of these
resources?
2c. Are there any
untapped opportu-
nities to make use
of these resources?
YOUR BUSINESS IDEAS
Based on your answers to question 1c and 2c, list as many
green business ideas as possible:
Idea 1: Idea 2: Idea 3: Idea 4:
Idea 5:
Idea 6:
12 | GREEN BUSINESS BOOKLET
2.3 Screening and
selecting your green
business idea
Once you have come up with your list of possi-
ble business ideas, you need to decide which
one is the most suitable for you.
To do this, you need to describe each idea in
detail and then screen them.
The GYB manual advises you to use the following
five questions to describe each of your ideas:
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢
Which need is fulfilled?
What product or service will the business
sell?
Who will the business sell to?
How will the business sell its product or
service?
How much will the business depend on and
impact the environment?
When completing the description and address-
ing the question on the environmental depend-
ence and impact, consider the following issues:
‚Ä¢
To what extent does the business depend on the surrounding natural environment (soil, wood,
charcoal, fish, wind, sun, water, etc.)?
...........................................................................................................................................................................
...........................................................................................................................................................................
‚Ä¢
Will the business have a positive impact on the environment (clean the water, improve the
soil, etc.)?
...........................................................................................................................................................................
...........................................................................................................................................................................
‚Ä¢
Will the business affect the environment in any negative way?
...........................................................................................................................................................................
...........................................................................................................................................................................
TYPE OF IMPACT Y N N/A
DETAILS ON THE NEGATIVE
IMPACTS & WAYS IN WHICH THEY
CAN BE AVOIDED OR MINIMIZED:
Will it use large amounts of fossil
fuel-based energy?
Will it use large amounts of water?
Will it use natural resources that are
in short supply or overexploited?
Will it require the use of harmful
chemicals?
Will it generate large amounts of
solid waste?
Will it create air pollution?
Will it create soil pollution?
Will it create water pollution?
The GYB manual then advises you to carry
out a ‚ÄúStrengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities
and Threats‚Äù (SWOT) analysis to assess a few
of your ideas and identify the best idea from
among your list.
When doing the SWOT exercise, you should
also keep in mind strengths, weaknesses, op-
portunities and threats that relate specifically
to the green dimension of your product.
GREEN BUSINESS BOOKLET
| 13
Green SWOT analysis example:
STRENGTHS WEAKNESSES
Conventional
strengths
High-revenue product
Green
strengths
Energy & material
efficient production pro-
cess can decrease costs
and increase profits
Conventional
weaknesses
Lack of skilled labour
Green
weaknesses
Lack of knowhow to
produce innovative prod-
ucts (e.g. solar panels)
needed for the idea
OPPORTUNITIES THREATS
Conventional
opportunities
Upcoming market for
this product
Green
opportunities
Large consumer base for
eco-friendly & healthy
products
Conventional
threats
Cheaper product availa-
ble in the market
Green
threats
Government subsidies
for competing, non-
green products
Important: Remember that even if your
main motivation is to help overcome an en-
vironmental problem, you cannot only think
about the environmental dimensions when
assessing your idea. It is equally important
to assess the economic dimensions such as
whether there will be sufficient demand for
the product or service. If your business idea
is not economically viable, it cannot succeed,
no matter how noble the idea may be. So you
need a sound business idea to be able to help
the environment!
14 | GREEN BUSINESS BOOKLET
3
YOUR GREEN
BUSINESS PLAN
As you now know, a green business may be a
business that sells green products or services,
or which operates according to green princi-
ples. Green businesses therefore contribute
to solving environmental problems and have a
minimal negative impact on the environment.
In order to launch your business, you need to
develop a business plan. The Start Your Busi-
ness (SYB) package has a detailed step-by-
step process for developing a business plan.
The business plan for your green business
needs to be adapted to include key elements
that are critical in starting a green business. In
addition to coming up with a viable green busi-
ness idea (see Chapter 2 for guidance), as you
The founder of Lemonbar decided to start a business that serves organic
drinks to a health-oriented clientele. To get started with your green business,
a first step is the development of a business plan.
plan for starting your green business it is im-
portant to also look at the business processes
and workplace behaviours and practices with
the objective of increasing resource efficiency,
clean production and reducing any possible
negative impacts on the environment.
This section of the GBB highlights some im-
portant green aspects to include in the busi-
ness plan.
A more in-depth overview of how to green your
processes by setting up an environmental
management system (EMS), also important for
your business plan, is provided in the following
chapter, as it is applicable not only to starting
enterprises, but also existing ones.
3.1 The green dimensions of
your business plan
Writing a green business plan is one of the
most important steps for starting up a green
business. The development of the plan is not
an overnight process and may take several
weeks to complete. The business plan for your
green business should cover all the aspects to
be considered before starting the business.
The main components of a business plan are
outlined in this chapter. For all the compo-
nents of your business plan, you need to make
sure that you add any green dimensions that
are relevant.
These green dimensions may relate to:
‚Ä¢
How the environment is affected by the par-
ticular business plan component: for exam-
ple, in terms of marketing, when consider-
ing distribution, long-distance transport will
be more damaging to the environment than
short distances.
GREEN BUSINESS BOOKLET
| 15
‚Ä¢
How each of the business plan components
is affected by the green characteristic of your
product/service: for example, when consider-
ing the price, you may be able to charge more
than your competitors because customers may
be willing to pay more for a green product, and
you may thereby enjoy a higher profit margin.
You will note that the business plan also in-
cludes a section on greening your business.
Greening is a cross-cutting issue that will come
up in most other sections of your business plan.
However, it is useful to give greening specific
attention through a section specifically devoted
to summarising all the required measures.
BUSINESS PLAN
COMPONENT
PURPOSE &
GREEN DIMENSION
Executive summary The executive summary is an outline of your green business idea. In addition to
the generic issues covered in a business plan, the summary should highlight its
green dimensions.
Your business idea All business plans are based on an idea. In describing your idea, you need to high-
light what makes it unique as a green business (in terms of the product/service or
process).
The marketing plan Your marketing plan needs to be based on a solid understanding of the market.
Once you know your market, you then need to develop a marketing plan based
on the 7 ‚ÄúP‚Äùs: Product, Price, Place, Promotion, People, Process, and Physical
Evidence. Consider the environmental dimension of these 7 ‚ÄúP‚Äùs when developing
the plan (for example, for ‚ÄúPrice‚Äù, whether you can charge a premium price).
Staff You will need to decide what your business‚Äô staffing needs are based on what tasks
need to be performed. When assessing what staff you need, consider whether any
additional technical skills are needed for your green product/service.
Organization and
management
Like any entrepreneur, you will need to decide on the form of business. A green
business can take one of many forms, including a sole proprietorship, a partner-
ship, or a cooperative, for example. You should weigh the pros and cons of each
before choosing the best form.
You will also need to consider all required taxes and permits and select an appro-
priate insurance policy; make sure to include environmental taxes and environ-
mental permits when doing so.
Buying for your
business
Your business will need to buy before you make or sell your products/services.
When buying for your business, consider how environmentally friendly the materi-
als or equipment you buy are.
Greening your
processes
Greening your processes covers a range of elements, starting from how environ-
mentally friendly your raw materials are to how you get your product to your final
consumers. To ensure the environmental-friendliness of your enterprise, you should
set up an environmental management system (EMS). This system will help you
track and improve your performance in key areas such as procurement, energy and
water consumption, pollution prevention, distribution and waste management.
Costing To be able to set your price and make a financial plan, you will need to calculate
the cost of your products. Keep in mind that you may incur some additional costs
at the outset for green investments relating to equipment, premises or skills, but
also that you will most likely make savings thanks to green practices such a re-
duced consumption of electricity or water, resulting in reduced utility bills.
Financial planning You need to be able to plan and monitor the financial situation of your business
using tools such as the profit plan and a cash flow plan. Like any other business,
your green business needs to perform financially, otherwise you will not be able to
keep it going!
Required start-up
capital
When estimating the required start-up capital, you will need to assess your needs
in terms of capital investment and working capital. Consider the elements required
for your business to be green while estimating this cost, and be realistic when
doing so.
Sources of start-up
capital
The most important types of start-up capital are owner‚Äôs equity and loans. Keep in
mind that there are also a number of institutions with special funding opportuni-
ties for green businesses."FOL:

Recap: A business plan is just like your pitch in the sense that it tells a story about why your business is a good bet. After pitching or getting some interest from an investor/granting organization, they might ask you for more information. Depending on the person, they might ask for a meeting or for a copy of your business plan. This business plan is your chance to show your professionalism and to dive into the details of your action plan. Many people think of a business plan as a long boring document that nobody looks at (which some people still do), but the business plan has evolved over time. It is detailed, but avoids unnecessary content. The main thing to show is where your business has been, where it is going, and how you plan on getting there.
Classical: 
Long 50 page documents that nobody reads. 
To many unnecessary details. 
Quantity over quality. 
Black and white, text heavy, boring.
Modern: 
There has been a shift to either pitch decks or short comprehensive plans.

3-5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

The executive summary is the first thing in a business plan, but the very last thing you write. After you write out the whole business plan, you pull out the most important information and create a one page teaser document. This will highlight all of the important points you want to make in a brief overview.  It explains:
Where you are now: Why do you do what you do? Why are you here? What is the problem you have identified and what is the solution (your product/service)?
Where you want to be: What is the end result you are looking to achieve? What is the long-term impact and growth potential of your business?
How you plan on getting there: How are you planning to accomplish this? How do you know this will work?

If it wasn‚Äôt covered in the earlier brainstorm, ask: Why is this section really important to have?
You can send this out to people who might be interested in your business. If they are interested, they might ask for more information
You should be able to sum up the key elements of your business plan in one page! Where are you now, where do you want to go, and how will you get there?
It will highlight the most important things. People don‚Äôt have to read the whole thing if they don‚Äôt want to.

Description: Tell us about your business. Who are you, why are you here, and what do you do (think challenge-solution)?

If you talk about your business one way in the executive summary, talk about it the same way in your business description!
Mission Statement, Vision, values, and Goals: What do you want to accomplish through the existence of your business (usually not financial accomplishments)?
Remember, write what works. If you think it is repetitive and not effective to write all of these, then don‚Äôt! You choose what will tell the best story for your business (where you have been, where you are going, how you will get there)
Products and services:  What are you offering, and what is its unique value? Be clear and obvious here.

### Recommendations for Applying the Integrated Business Resilience Framework & Green Considerations

After reviewing the slides, facilitator notes, and the **Green Business Booklet**, I see several opportunities to **integrate green business elements** into your session while aligning with your client's needs.

---

### **1. Strengthening Green Business Considerations in Each Section**
Your **Integrated Business Resilience Framework** likely focuses on long-term sustainability, adaptability, and risk management. These concepts naturally align with the green business approach. Here‚Äôs how you can integrate these ideas into key parts of the business plan framework:

#### **a. Executive Summary**
- **Add:** A line emphasizing **how sustainability is a competitive advantage** in the market.
- **Example:** ‚ÄúBy integrating green practices, we reduce costs, attract environmentally conscious customers, and position our business for long-term success.‚Äù

#### **b. Business Description**
- **Include:** A dedicated bullet point explaining how sustainability is embedded in the business model (either through a green product, service, or process).
- **Example:** ‚ÄúOur business prioritizes sustainability by using recycled materials, reducing waste, and optimizing supply chain logistics for minimal carbon impact.‚Äù

#### **c. Market Analysis**
- **Enhance:** By incorporating insights into the growing demand for sustainable products/services.
- **Example Prompts for Discussion:**
  - What are key **regulatory trends** favoring green businesses?
  - How does eco-conscious consumer behavior create **market opportunities**?
  - Are there **certifications or green funding** opportunities available?

#### **d. Action Plan**
- **Add:** A ‚ÄúGreening Your Business‚Äù section that includes specific actions related to environmental sustainability (e.g., sustainable sourcing, waste reduction, energy efficiency).
- **Prompt:** ‚ÄúHow can we incorporate environmental impact reduction in our operations and supply chain?‚Äù

#### **e. Financial Projections**
- **Adjust:** The financial section should highlight **cost savings from green practices** and potential access to **grants, impact investment, or subsidies for green businesses**.

Recap: A business plan is just like your pitch in the sense that it tells a story about why your business is a good bet. After pitching or getting some interest from an investor/granting organization, they might ask you for more information. Depending on the person, they might ask for a meeting or for a copy of your business plan. This business plan is your chance to show your professionalism and to dive into the details of your action plan. Many people think of a business plan as a long boring document that nobody looks at (which some people still do), but the business plan has evolved over time. It is detailed, but avoids unnecessary content. The main thing to show is where your business has been, where it is going, and how you plan on getting there.
Classical: 
Long 50 page documents that nobody reads. 
To many unnecessary details. 
Quantity over quality. 
Black and white, text heavy, boring.
Modern: 
There has been a shift to either pitch decks or short comprehensive plans. 
These business plans are action oriented and interesting for the reader. 
Quality over quantity.
Represents your brand, highly visual, interesting.

All of those points are correct, what we will do now is cover some of the key elements that should be included in a business plan. Here are the slide text and facilitator notes [[[SUPPLY CHAIN MANAGEMENT
----
Agenda
----
9:00 | Settle in
9:15 | Product development activity
10:15 | break
10:30 | Supply chain best practices
11:10 | Supply chain mapping
12:00 | Wrap up
----

9:00 | Settle in
Tea/coffee
Answer entrepreneur questions. 

9:15 | Begin the session
Good morning everyone! How are you doing today?¬†
Today we will be talking about your supply chain. Many of your products/services have some physical element to it. We will break down how you get those things and how they impact your business and customers. If you don‚Äôt have a physical element to your business (many tech businesses), this information is still good to know. A lot of what we will talk about are just good business practices in general.  
1

Experience a rapid product development process.
Understand the different parts of your supply chain.
Evaluate how to add value along your supply chain.

1 minute: Objectives

Experience a rapid product development process.
Understand the different parts of your supply chain.
Evaluate how to add value along your supply chain.
2

DEVELOP A NEW PRODUCT
1 hour: Activity (you can find an alternate online activity on the drive)
5 Minutes: Explanation
Entrepreneurs will work in groups to go through a rapid product development process.
Tell everyone they are a business developing a new product that will be sold to the training team: a paper airplane. The plane has to fly and look good. The price will reflect its design, functionality, and how efficiently it is produced. Based on the trainers' thoughts on your plane, they will give your plane a selling price.
Break the group into small teams (about 3 people per team).
The trainer should have prototyping materials ready, including paper, markers, stickers, etc. These items are available to the entrepreneurs to continue using as they want throughout the entire game. They can use whatever they want.
Entrepreneurs are free to continue asking the trainers (the people buying the planes) questions about the activity/type of plane to design (they can do user research to find out more about how to design their plane based on customers' needs/wants).
Entrepreneurs should feel free to work with their groups wherever they are comfortable.
55 Minutes: Activity
10 minutes: The team will have 10 minutes to design a new product (paper airplane). Encourage them to consider how to make an effective design while using materials efficiently.
10 minutes: Each group will pitch their plane to the trainer.
The trainer will evaluate functionality, design, and the overall pitch to determine a price for each plane.
The trainer can also consider the amount of work that went into the plane design. Did the team create a design that maximized performance while minimizing wasted materials?
The trainer should set prices like $2, $5, $10, $15, $20 depending on detail and flying capabilities. Try to have a variety of prices.
Tell them that each plane costs $5 to make (make it all the same to keep it simple). When we price the plane, some people will get better margins or worse margins.
And some people would be able to produce a lot or a little, causing different levels of profitability. Some designs might be more efficient, allowing for faster production or lower costs. It depends on how the game goes, but interesting conversations come up.
15 Minutes: Scaling Up the Production
Announce to the groups that you like all of the planes they pitched and you would like to purchase them for your store.
They will have 10 minutes to produce 15 of the planes they pitched.
Halfway through this time (after about 7 minutes), announce a change in demand:
You are expecting high demand for these planes after a focus group, and you would like to order 25 planes instead.
Announce that you will extend the delivery time by 5 additional minutes (13 minutes left for production).
15 Minutes: Evaluation & Discussion
Bring everyone back and tell people production has stopped‚Äîthey must now deliver their products.
The trainer will now pay each group for their product.
Count each plane that matches the one they pitched. Reject planes that do not work or do not match what they pitched to you.
Multiply the number of accepted planes by the price that was set before mass production.
Subtract $5 for each plane they made (even if the plane was rejected because they produced it).
Calculate who made the most money!
Trainer Tip: Make it more fun by offering a small piece of candy for each $ of profit they made. (Some teams might realize that a more efficient process leads to higher profits!) Some people might owe you candy at the end if they weren‚Äôt profitable‚Ä¶. But don‚Äôt actually make them give you candy.

The trainer should set prices like $2, $5, $10, $15, $20 depending on detail and flying capabilities. Try to have a variety of prices.
Tell them that each plane costs $5 to make (make it all the same to keep it simple)- When we price the plane some people will get better margins or worse margins. And some people would be able to produce a lot or a little causing different levels of profitability. It depends on how the game goes, but interesting conversations come up.

15 minutes: Announce to the groups that you like all of the planes they pitched and you would like to purchase them for your store. They will have 10 minutes to produce 15 of the planes they pitched. 
When you are halfway through this time (after about 7 minutes), announce to the group that you would like to change your order. You are expecting high demand for these planes after a focus group and you would like to order 25 planes instead. 
Announce that you will extend the delivery time by 5 additional minutes (13 minutes left for production).
 15 minutes: Bring everyone back and tell people production has stopped and they need to deliver their products to you.
The trainer will now pay each group for their product
Count each plane that matches the one they pitched. Reject planes that do not work or do not match what they pitched to you.
Multiply the number of accepted planes by the price that was set before mass production. 
Subtract $5 for each plane that they made (even if the plane was rejected because they produced it)
Calculate who made the most money! 
Trainer tip: Make it more fun by offering a small piece of candy for each $of profit they made. (Some people might owe you candy at the end if they weren‚Äôt profitable‚Ä¶. But don‚Äôt actually make them give you candy).

ADAPT QUICKLY
5 minutes: Discussion

Another technique to help your supply chain is by enabling yourself to be able to adapt quickly. In the activity we did, we created 1 item, imagine doing this for hundreds or thousands of items. What if you were working in several cities and you had many employees to get onboard a new project? What would you do if you had to adapt quickly? What systems should you have in place to allow for quick and adaptive responses? Sometimes there are crises that happen (Coronavirus for example) that totally change things. How will your business adapt quickly and efficiently? 

Ask: What are ways that you can enable yourself to adapt quickly and respond to change?
Potential answers: 
Integrated supply chain: Create a supply chain that connects all the different partners in one place through a system that facilitates good communication and efficiency. Ask: What can you do to create an ‚Äúintegrated supply chain‚Äù?
Coordinate the movement of your products and services. Track your shipments or other arrangements with suppliers online. Although you might not have a digital system, you can ask the person to give you weekly updates on the status of your deliveries.  
Make sure that there is always a path for clear information flows with key partners (see communication point below)
Have each of your partners in your supply chain communicating with each if relevant. 
Reduce the number of steps in your supply chain, or find a supplier that can deal with multiple steps (or you can take control of more steps)
Use technology to manage the supply chain more efficiently and know what is happening at each step. There is software for this, but probably not relevant for businesses at this stage
Etc‚Ä¶

Communication with partners:
Have a system to quickly share information with key partners (tell a supplier about change in demand, for example)
This could be through the phone, email, or something else, but it can be slow and is susceptible to a lot of human error. 
You can purchase online systems 
Designate certain employees to be the communicators to certain partners
Etc‚Ä¶
Communication with your team:
Does the team know why they are doing this? 
Make a clear connection between marketing, design, procurement, and other teams in your organization
What is the system in place to communicate big news and information? ‚Äì Which system is best to make sure key information is made clear to the team and things aren‚Äôt lost along the way?
Slack
Email?
Face to face?
Understand customers: 
Internet (gather data on them)
Ask them (surveys, feedback, SM, etc‚Ä¶)
Learn from other parts of the supply chain (integrate processes so you can observe changes in demand)
Etc...

Recap: Be responsive to changing customer demands and changing markets. Do this by putting systems in place to be able to forecast potential trends and also communicate with key partners to adapt quickly.

INVENTORY MANAGEMENT
5 minutes: Discussion

Before you get into any agreement, make sure that you fully understand your capabilities before you agree to anything. 
Ask: What are the things that you should consider while managing inventory? What systems can you put in place to make sure that your inventory is being managed well?
Potential answers:
Categorize your assets in a logical way so that you always know what is there and you can easily organize information. This prevents unnecessary purchases and waste. 
Digitize your inventory. Consider buying a software to manage inventory. Or keep digital records by tracking your purchases and sales. Digital tracking helps prevent overstocking or running out of key materials.
Manage inventory based on safety levels. Make sure you set a range on how much inventory you need at one time. You don‚Äôt want too much because it can be expensive to store, materials can expire or degrade, and space can be wasted, etc‚Ä¶ And you don‚Äôt want to run out of materials because then you miss out on sales opportunities or slow down production! Find a good level, and stick to it. Keep records so you can learn about seasonal trends over time (in case inventory changes seasonally, safety levels might change too)
Perform routine checks. Check in on your inventory now and again to make sure that your digital records are accurate. Maybe things aren‚Äôt being managed correctly causing broken, stolen, or damaged products.
Etc‚Ä¶

SUPPLY CHAIN MAPPING
10 minutes: Brainstorm

A Supply Chain is the entire system of producing and delivering a product or a service, from the very beginning stage of sourcing the raw materials to the final customer. 
Let‚Äôs do an example together. Let‚Äôs take a simple mug and break down its supply chain together and identify areas to make a more efficient supply chain.
Use some of the questions below to prompt the group to map out the full supply chain for a mug (or another example):
What are the raw materials needed for this product? Where are they found?
What are the steps involved in making this product? Where does each step in the production take place?
What energy is needed to produce this item? Where does that energy come from?
What kind of transportation, if any, is needed at each stage of the production process, including getting the finished product to you?
Which steps does the business control vs other companies? Are there opportunities for the business to control more? Would it be a good idea to take control?
Potential answer for the supply chain mapping of a mug:
Purchase the best materials (procurement) ‚Äì Maybe we buy the ceramic mugs from China and cardboard boxes for packaging from another retailer in China. These items get shipped through Alibaba.
Ask: What should you consider during the procurement stage? 
Take into consideration customers preferences
Consider your brand
Consider your budget
How convenient is it to buy this material? 

Manufacturing and operations‚Äì We are not manufacturing anything because we pre-order from China, but we need to package and label all the products to prepare for shipping to the customers. This will happen in the office you rented with your small team. 
Ask: What should you consider during the manufacturing and operations stage? 
Manage time limits and employees
Complete all tasks on time and with high quality
Clean up and prepare for continued work

Logistics and transportation ‚Äì We need to store and ship all the mugs to the customers address. We will store the items in our store. We use a 3rd party delivery company and also sell from our storefront. 
Ask: What should you consider during the logistics and transportation stage? 
How will your packaging affect storage, transportation, and delivery? 
How can you ensure timely delivery?
Where will you store your product? 
How will you get the product to your customers? 

Ikea example: Take the case of Ikea ‚Äì its ‚ÄòBang‚Äô mug has been redesigned many times to realize shipping cost savings (pictures show first and final versions of the cups). Originally, 864 mugs would fit into a pallet; after redesign a pallet held 1,280 mugs. With a further redesign 2,024 mugs could be held. This act of packaging ingenuity and attention to detail reduced its shipping costs by 60%. In addition, IKEA now owns a huge number of forests so that it controls some areas of its own supply. They use wood from this forest in their own products instead of paying a little bit more for someone else to provide the wood. They are able to profit off of this because they are a huge company and benefit from economies of scale.

10 minutes: Discussion
Your supply chain has a big impact on your business, people, and the environment. Some supply chains are completely local, while others have supply chains that are around the world. Every decision you make on how to source, produce, transport, sell your product/materials has an impact. 
Ask: How can you make sure that your supply chain is sustainable, cost effective, and creating a positive impact?
Potential answers:
Make sure that each step of your supply chain is sourcing their supplies ethically (don‚Äôt use sweatshops, child labor, causing environmental harm, etc‚Ä¶)
Produce as much as you can locally to reduce transportation costs, CO2 emissions, and provide jobs to the local economy
Cut costs by renegotiating partnerships or cutting out steps all together
Be more efficient and reduce waste wherever you can
Optimize inventory and transportation by using systems and data analytics
Improve functionality by making things easier and saving time
A more efficient and sustainable supply chain can be a great source of value creation
You can cut costs and increase your profitability
You can cut costs and pass savings over to your customers, increasing value for them
You can create value for customers and stakeholders by being more sustainable and eco friendly

	-	6	Added New Content	-	"""VALUES ORIENTED BUSINESS MODEL

5 minutes: Lecture

So we talked about this already a little bit, but I want to show how the different pieces of BMC fits together
Explain how the BMC fits together as a story:
Start with the right side: 
You have a product that delivers value (value proposition) to your different customer segments. If we want them to know about the product/value offered, we use different channels to reach them. Once we have reached the customer segments, we want to build relationships with them to get them coming back. Delivering value to your customers allows you to make sales and bring in revenue (maybe they even bring friends along). 
Where have you seen this before? 
This is what they did during Ignite!
You should have a clear picture of your customers, what they care about, how to reach them, and have an idea of how you will actually make money through this interaction. 

Move on to the left side:
Next let‚Äôs look at all the key activities you need to do in order to make this a reality. You need to put in work and resources to build and deliver the value you promised to your customers. There are a lot of activities and resources that go into the consistent delivery of value to your customers (running your business). You usually can‚Äôt do it all yourself. In this case, you need to find the right partners to help you achieve your tasks. These partners can help by providing resources (human, financial, etc‚Ä¶) or by taking responsibility for some key activities. All of this costs money to do. 

Conclusion: In the next slides, we are going to go point by point on the BMC to understand it more. We will discuss the different parts as a group and go over an example. After that, there will be time to apply it to your business. Keep in mind that this session will stay fairly high level for now. It is about getting a snapshot, not going into detail! We will go into detail during future sessions.

Transition to the next slide: We will start with the value proposition."""

	17	21	Updated Wording in Speaker Notes	"""<5 minutes: Discussion

What are key resources? How do we get them? 
Potential answers:
Key resources are the personnel, tools, and budget the team will need access to 
Every business model requires Key Resources. Your resources allow your enterprise to create and offer a Value Proposition, reach markets, maintain relationships with Customer Segments, and earn revenues. 
Different Key Resources are needed depending on the type of business model (some business need a lot of cash on hand while others need a lot of human resources)
Key resources can be owned or leased by the company or acquired from key partners (including investors).
Examples:
Physical resources (tangible assets)
Financial resources (cash), 
Intellectual resources
Human resources. 

If you are having trouble identifying the right key activities, ask yourself the following:
What Key Resources do our Value Propositions require?
Our Distribution Channels?
Customer Relationships?
Revenue Streams?

--------
More details on different common key resources. There is no need to cover them in detail. If you cover these points, you should focus on when to use these types, talk about the pros and cons of each. It shouldn‚Äôt be about explaining definitions.
--------
Types of Key Resources: Key Resources can be categorized as follows:
Physical: This category includes physical assets such as manufacturing facilities, buildings, vehicles, machines, systems, point-of-sales systems, and distribution networks. Retailers like Wal-Mart and Amazon.com rely heavily on physical resources, which are often capital-intensive. The former has an enormous global network of stores and related logistics infrastructure. The latter has an extensive IT, warehouse, and logistics infrastructure.
Intellectual Property: Intellectual property resources such as brands, proprietary knowledge, patents and copyrights, partnerships, and customer databases are increasingly important components of a strong business model. Intellectual property resources are difficult to develop but when successfully created may offer substantial value. Consumer goods companies such as Nike and Sony rely heavily on their brand as a Key Resource. Microsoft and SAP depend on software and related intellectual property developed over many years. Qualcomm, a designer and supplier of chipsets for broadband mobile devices, built its business model around patented microchip designs that earn the company substantial licensing fees.
Human: Every enterprise requires human resources, but people are particularly prominent in certain business models. For example, human resources are crucial in knowledge-intensive and creative industries. A pharmaceutical company such as Novartis, for example, relies heavily on human resources: its business model is predicated on an army of experienced scientists and a large and skilled sales force.
Financial: Some business models call for financial resources and/or financial guarantees, such as cash, lines of credit, or a stock option pool for hiring key employees. Ericsson, the telecom manufacturer, provides an example of financial resource leverage within a business model. Ericsson may opt to borrow funds from banks and capital markets, then use a portion of the proceeds to provide vendor financing to equipment customers, thus ensuring that orders are placed with Ericsson rather than competitors."""	"""Discussion (5 minutes)
Prompt:
What are key resources? How do we get them?
Potential answers:
Key resources are the personnel, tools, and budget the team will need access to.
Every business model requires Key Resources‚Äîthese enable an enterprise to:
Create and offer a Value Proposition
Reach markets and maintain Customer Relationships
Generate Revenue Streams
Different businesses rely on different types of key resources.
Some require high cash flow (e.g., retail, manufacturing).
Others rely on skilled human resources (e.g., consulting, software development).
Key resources can be owned, leased, or acquired from key partners (e.g., investors, suppliers, collaborators).

Refining the Discussion with Values & Resilience Considerations
Expand the conversation beyond traditional resources by integrating values-aligned resources:
How do your key resources align with your values?
Example: Tech company deciding between high-speed but energy-intensive servers vs. solar-powered servers.
Which resources are most vulnerable to supply chain disruptions, price volatility, or regulation changes?
Example: Businesses that relied on non-renewable materials saw supply chain delays during COVID.
Mitigation: Consider sustainable alternatives that increase stability and reduce long-term costs.
How could prioritizing sustainability or ethical sourcing make your business more resilient?
Example: Fair-trade coffee brands secure long-term supplier loyalty, ensuring stable pricing.

Key Resource Categories & Considerations
1. Physical Resources:
Facilities, buildings, vehicles, hardware, logistics networks
Values Lens: Are these resources energy-efficient, responsibly sourced, or adaptable?
Example: A logistics company using fuel-efficient vehicles to reduce costs and emissions.
2. Intellectual Property (IP):
Brand identity, patents, proprietary technology, databases, algorithms
Values Lens: Are these resources accessible, open-source, or ethically developed?
Example: Open-source software companies that enable collaboration while maintaining a revenue model.
3. Human Resources:
Employees, contractors, advisors
Values Lens: Are hiring, retention, and training practices equitable, ethical, and inclusive?
Example: Businesses that provide fair wages and growth opportunities retain employees longer.
4. Financial Resources:
Capital, investments, revenue streams
Values Lens: Is funding aligned with the company‚Äôs mission? Are there ethical finance models?
Example: A sustainable brand choosing impact investors over venture capital for long-term alignment.

Activity ‚Äì Resource Resilience Mapping (10 minutes)
Goal: Help participants assess their resources beyond traditional needs‚Äîconsidering values, resilience, and efficiency.
List Your Resources: Identify the key resources required for business success.
Assess Their Alignment: Are these resources chosen for cost, speed, sustainability, ethics, or resilience?
Risk Assessment:
Which resources are most vulnerable to price fluctuations, shortages, or regulatory changes?
Can alternatives improve stability? (e.g., renewable energy, local sourcing)
Values Integration:
How could sustainability, ethics, or durability enhance long-term success?
Example: If using imported raw materials, could switching to local suppliers reduce risk and support community businesses?
Reflection: Discuss findings with a partner or small group‚Äîwhat surprised them? Any action items identified?""

QOWA (meaning ""strength"" in Arabic) was an ambitious 2007 initiative by UNICEF Innovation Unit that aimed to:

Use simple technology solutions to connect children
Help restore normalcy and resilience for conflict-affected children
Roll out across multiple countries in the Middle East region
Why QOWA Failed in Prototyping?
1. Failure to Design with the User (Principle 1)
Project plans were developed by experts without involving the end users (out-of-school Iraqi children)
Lacked understanding of actual resources, needs, challenges, and usage patterns of the target population
Failed to conduct proper field research on how people access and use information
Did not budget or plan for the logistical complexity of including end users in the design process

Hardware and software capabilities
Logistics in conflict zones
Connectivity infrastructure
Technical capacity
Partnership structures
Tried to build ""a massive, globally interconnected classroom and resource library"" in ""the most resource-scarce and conflict-affected areas""
Lacked organizational experience in implementing innovations of this scale and complexity
